intro: Bupleurum leucocladum var. typicum, commonly known as the white-flowered bupleurum, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of central and southern Europe. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes plants like carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, which bloom in early summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun to partial shade, often growing in rocky or gravelly habitats. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and traditional herbal practices.
